#Text=Set Up a Tattoo Shop
#Text=Are you an artist or have artistic tendencies ?
#Text=Are you interested in taking your art to the most versatile canvas available , which is the skin ?
#Text=Tattooing is popular in many areas of the world and is found in many different cultures .
#Text=You can capitalize on the popularity of tattooing by setting up a tattoo shop .
#Text=If you have ever wanted to run your own business as a tattoo artist , read on to learn how to set up a tattoo shop .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Enroll in a tattoo artist apprenticeship program .
#Text=This program can take you 12 to 24 months to complete , but it could also be very expensive .

#Text=You will gain the experience you need to become a tattoo artist , which can come in handy because you typically need to have experience in a hands-on program before you can start your own tattoo business .
#Text=You wo n't be tattooing right away , but the program is vital to your experience .
#Text=Find a location for your shop .
#Text=Set up a tattoo shop in a place where there is a lot of automotive and pedestrian traffic to help increase your potential for walk-ins .
#Text=When people can see your business from the road or as they are walking past , they may be more likely to remember it and visit later .
#Text=Follow all laws involving tattoos in your local area .
#Text=The requirements for starting a tattoo business will vary based on where you want to run it .
#Text=There are health and safety concerns with the art of tattooing , and you will likely be subject to inspections .
#Text=You also may need to have special permits to operate .
#Text=Your local health department can help you determine what licensing is needed for tattooing .
#Text=Purchase all the tattooing equipment you need .
#Text=You wo n't need to buy everything at once , and you do n't have to buy everything brand new .
#Text=Look in classified papers and online to find used equipment .
#Text=You will need things such as a tattoo gun , needles , ink , transfers , furniture for the lobby , and a cash register .
#Text=Advertise your shop through numerous outlets .
#Text=You can advertise online through paid campaigns and a business website or through social media .
#Text=You can advertise locally with business cards and flyers .
#Text=If your budget allows , you can also try radio or TV advertising .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Consider adding a credit card machine to your store so you can accept more than just cash for payment .
#Text=If you can include piercing in your apprenticeship , this is an excellent way to bring in more business .
#Text=If you do not want to do piercing yourself , you may be able to hire someone who will .
#Text=The requirements for piercing will also be provided by your local health department .
#Text=Anyone who is acting as a tattoo artist in your shop must hold the necessary certifications .
#Text=Employees who are not tattooing or piercing will not need certification .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Always make sure to have customers sign the necessary consent and waiver forms before you begin the tattoo .
#Text=Provide adequate after-care instructions to your customers at the conclusion of the session .
#Text=Always check ID to ensure your customers are of the proper age to get a tattoo .
#Text=Residents must be at least 18 years old to get a tattoo unless they live in Illinois or South Carolina , where they need to be at least 21 .

#Text=While most states allow tattooing of minors with parental consent , it is illegal in Alaska , California , Illinois , Iowa , Kansas , Maine , Maryland , Massachusetts , Mississippi , Nevada , New Hampshire , New York , North Carolina , Oklahoma , Oregon , Rhode Island , Washington , and Wisconsin .
#Text=Always check ID to ensure your customers are of the proper age to get a piercing .
#Text=All states require written parental consent to allow a minor to receive any piercing .
#Text=Most states define minor as younger than 18 , whereas South Carolina and Illinois define a minor as anyone under age 21 .
